statement.p:
Suppose that a subspace W of \real^3 has a basis formed by
\vvec_1=\threevec111, \hspace{24pt} \vvec_2=\threevec1{-2}{-2}.
Find an orthogonal basis for W.
Find an orthonormal basis for W.
Find the matrix P that projects vectors orthogonally onto W.
Find the orthogonal projection of \threevec34{-2} onto W.

Consider the basis of \real^3 given by the vectors
\vvec_1=\threevec2{-2}2,\hspace{24pt} \vvec_2=\threevec{-1}{-3}1,\hspace{24pt} \vvec_3=\threevec{2}0{-5}.
Apply the Gram-Schmit orthogonalization algorithm to find an orthonormal basis \uvec_1, \uvec_2, \uvec_3 for \real^3.
If A is the 3\times3 whose columns are \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3, find the QR factorization of A.
Suppose that we want to solve the equation A\xvec=\bvec = \threevec{-9}17, which we can rewrite as QR\xvec = \bvec.
If we set \yvec=R\xvec, explain why the equation Q\yvec=\bvec is computationally easy to solve.
Explain why the equation R\xvec=\yvec is computationally easy to solve.
Find the solution \xvec.

Consider the vectors
\vvec_1=\fivevec1{-1}{-1}11,\hspace{24pt} \vvec_2=\fivevec2{1}{4}{-4}2,\hspace{24pt} \vvec_3=\fivevec5{-4}{-3}71
and the subspace W of \real^5 that they span.
Find an orthonormal basis for W.
Find the 5\times5 matrix that projects vectors orthogonally onto W.
Find \bhat, the orthogonal projection of \bvec=\fivevec{-8}3{-12}8{-4} onto W.
Express \bhat as a linear combination of \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3.

Consider the set of vectors
\vvec_1=\threevec211,\hspace{24pt} \vvec_2=\threevec122,\hspace{24pt} \vvec_3=\threevec300.
What happens when we apply the Gram-Schmit orthogonalization algorithm?
Why does the algorithm fail to produce an orthogonal basis for \real^3?

Suppose that A is a matrix with linearly independent columns and having the factorization A=QR. Determine whether the following statements are true or false and explain your thinking.
It follows that R=Q^TA.
The matrix R is invertible.
The product Q^TQ projects vectors orthogonally onto \col(A).
The columns of Q are an orthogonal basis for \col(A).
The orthogonal complement \col(A)^\perp = \nul(Q^T).

Suppose we have the QR factorization A=QR, where A is a 7\times 4 matrix.
What is the shape of the product QQ^T? Explain the significance of this product.
What is the shape of the product Q^TQ? Explain the significance of this product.
What is the shape of the matrix R?
If R is a diagonal matrix, what can you say about the columns of A?

Suppose we have the QR factorization A=QR where the columns of A are \avec_1,\avec_2,\ldots,\avec_n and the columns of R are \rvec_1,\rvec_2,\ldots,\rvec_n.
How can the matrix product A^TA be expressed in terms of dot products?
How can the matrix product R^TR be expressed in terms of dot products?
Explain why A^TA=R^TR.
Explain why the angle between \avec_i and \avec_j is the same as the angle between \rvec_i and \rvec_j.
